DB_w_approach: I tried to look at the y-axis and make sure I was doing what I was supposed to.
I always tried to estimate the actual number the graphs were representing, especially in the misleading ones.
I assumed they were skewing so adjusted the influence

Even though they were misleading, the data was still there. In terms of a few different subjects, if the bars seemed widely different and it was only a 2 point difference... that's still big on a scale from 1-3 (if that makes sense?) so yes, they were misleading and could be problematic for buyers or marketing teams or whatever. But for this survey, a big and a little line within a sample is still a big difference, regardless of the actual numerical value.

I tried to carefully judge the range of the y-axis so that I got a intuitive sense of the difference between the two that I was comparing. I also thought a lot about the difference or change as a percentage to help judge how much difference there was between the two variables

I tried to set the bottom  value as a zero, and use the height of the bars to find a difference for each bar. For example if it started at 500, I would find a bar with a height of 750 having a value of 250, while a bar with a height of 1000, would have a value of 500.
I would also pay attention to the values for the y-axis, if it was in billions, percentages, millions, etc.
See how far apart they were in actual y-axis value and then comparing to the other values on the x axis to see if they were that far off
I just went with how the bars look. I made my judgments by comparing the area of both bars, numbers didn't matter to me.
I approached the graphs that were misleading the same way than the others, looking at the values on the y-axis
I look at the scale on the y-axis, and then judge the approximate value of each bar, then make my judgement call as to how different the two numbers are.
I measured according to the height of the graft.
I just used my best visual judgement.
If it was a misleading graph then I thought of the differences in bar size as smaller than they actually looked.
I read the information fully before making a judgement

DB_w_approach: For the graphs that were misleading, I compared the difference in values between them and estimated whether the difference in values were significant or not in answering the questions.

As far as graphs that were misleading, I just look closely at the graphs to tell me whether they were or not. If I felt the difference between two sets of data wasn't as large as it appeared, I noticed it.

For graphs that were misleading I always reduced my judgement of differences between bars due to the fact that the axis didn't start at 0 which magnifies the difference. I was more skeptical and thought the actual difference must be smaller than what the graph made it look like.
I tried to really study the values on the y-axis to see how misleading the graphs were to determine how different the data was.
The graphs that were misleading, I almost exclusively used the values on the y-axis and then used my judgement based on the different between the numbers, not what the graphed looked like at all.

If the Y axis did not start at zero, I paid more careful attention to what the values were. For every graph, I looked at the first point in question and made note of roughly (I couldn't be exact without hash marks for every value on the y axis) the value for that one was and then looked at the value for the second item in question and used the disparity to make my judgment. I also took into account whether the value on the y axis was percentage or millions, or whatever to make my judgment.

DB_nw_notice: I noticed that you can make something look like a huge difference using a smaller scale.

When I encountered a misleading graph, I made a special note in my head to be careful with how I interpret the data since it is visually skewed. I believe that using the numbers on the y-axis should negate most of the effects of the misleading graphs, though.
I was immediately looking to see if it started at zero. If it didn't, I automatically labeled the graph as misleading.
I would always consider each comparison in terms of "What % different are these two groups?" and then I would read the y-axis values.  This allowed me to avoid being misled by the misleading graphs.
